My biggest fear is that Wall Street is returning to the unregulated market in mortgage-backed securities, and collateralized debt obligations, tranches and credit default swaps which led up to the Great Recession, and the FED will have to decide when to get back into QE and put a lot more junk debt onto its balance sheet.

In an address to the Mortgage Bankers Association on October 20th, some of whose former members were the poster boys of unfettered greed, Mel Watt, the head of the FHFA, which controls Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae, announced that they would buy mortgages with loan-to-value ratios of 95-97%. In other words, they would require only 3-5% down, and when mortgage bankers get creative with "values," we're right back to no money down and even cash-out subprime loans, the kind Wall Street wanted because their interest rates re-set quickly and substantially higher, that is until borrowers could no longer afford them. Then nobody wanted them.

Then what will we do?

We have a fixed concept of "old" in America: the time when people give up, sit down and don't do anything. An entire industry is dedicated to encouraging people to think about this period in their lives, with massive advertising campaigns, so they will save money, hand it over to investment advisors, praying silently every day that the money doesn't run out before they do. Instead, we should pray that our lives out run the money. "Retirement" as a social concept is a manufactured idea that started to be pushed aggressively during the Great Depression to free up jobs for younger people when half the nation was out of work.

I once met a retired 65 yr. old woman in England who traveled four days a week by train about 100 miles each way to do charity work in London. People in France retire in their 50s and spend the next 30 yrs. playing Bocce ball and going on summer vacations with the whole family, three generations (at least). Police officers, firefighters and military people can retire with close to full pay even by their late 40s or early 50s. Then what?

The point, overall, is that what we believe old age to be and what it actually is are vastly different concepts. We have been conditioned to think of older people as frail, wobbling around muttering to themselves. So, when the time comes, we imitate what we've seen and been taught.

A lot of the barriers of older age are in our heads. Those ideas give a measure of comfort for people who are weary and want to give up anyway.

RE: Keynes teaches "in the long run we are dead." The implication is that we should live for today, not save for tomorrow.

No. This is completely the opposite of what Keynes was saying in the General Theory. He was quite concerned with the long run--but you can't be concerned with JUST this.

Keynes full quote: "In the long run we are all dead. Economists set themselves too easy, too useless a task if in tempestuous seasons they can only tell us that when the storm is long past the ocean is flat again."

Keynes was attacking the austerian / Andrew Mellon position on the Depression--the economic storm at the time, in which saving in a deflationary environment doesn't work--advocating NO govt intervention, as the disarrayed economic system could work itself out. As Mellon put it to Pres. Hoover: ""liquidate labor, liquidate stocks, liquidate farmers, liquidate real estate... it will purge the rottenness out of the system. High costs of living and high living will come down. People will work harder, live a more moral life. . . ." (And easy for Mellon to say, in not all having to worry about taking this medicine--and thus showing his own smug moral superiority . . .).

Mellon's selfish advice ignored that the short term was ruining a lot of people--to state the economic equivalent: that eventually the ocean will be flat again just ignores all the people that were tossed overboard during the storm, and is not a call for prescription for hedonism.

I love the formulation that a billionaire does not an economic sage make. But in the minds of many in the media, government and the general public, successful (or even unsuccessful, but very loud) businesspeople are the ones with the best plans for everything, whether it should be run like a business (i.e., a business) or not (i.e., a school, a church, a national government).

This isn't to say that we can't learn from successful businesses, but all too often, we are told that business execs know what's best for the rest of us, with resulting horrible policies. Only they don't, especially when it comes to the economy. And as the 2008-9 global economic crisis proved yet again, financial industry executives really shouldn't be listened to, but rather kept under very close watch!

An added problem is that in business schools there is not a strong body of theory, especially predictive theory. Businesses (& business people) generally do not spend much time analyzing failure. They are only interested in success. Economics may be 'the dismal science', but it has a strong body of theory and makes serious efforts to be scientific.

Business schools teach and learn by anecdote study, individual stories, cases, usually of success or of solved problems. There is rarely the attempt at controlled studies, double blind, design of experiments, or other tools of science and academic engineering. There is no effort to develop standard models that represent the successful business or the failing business.

And worst of all, business history is almost entirely ignored except to spin happy tales of brilliant men achieving success over time. Institutional memory fades with shredding of document requirements, retirements, and lay-offs. Often there is no real memory of why and how failure or success really happened. Thus, business culture abhors science, and seeks to hide its history from tax men, regulators, and the public. Such people have no useful experience in things like understanding and running economies.

Animal cooperation is more of the form of:  instrumental cooperation,  for instance, lions or chimpanzees hunting together.  Human cooperation is much tighter.  Only humans divide a kill into equal portions.  Only humans play music together, following the same key, tempo, dynamics, rhythm, time signature, and melody.  Only humans share information with each other via a system of universally agreed upon rules.  Language would never have evolved in Chimpanzees because of the presence of the alpha male which prevents a level playing field from emerging.

What is voting for then?  Why does everyone in North America drive on the right side of the street?  Why do people play team sports if they are not willing to limit their behaviour for the sake of the collectivity?
Thomas: Male chimpanzees step on and crush their own children. I can't talk about animals like that forming a coalition. Why don't they form a coalition not to step on their kids and kill them?

When I think of the term "political" I think of collective choice. Politics is the result of agreements between people or groups of people. Chimpanzees don't choose their alpha male, he or his coalition forces itself on the rest of the chimps. Where humans are different than animals is that we agree to rules that we expect everyone else to follow. In other words we agree to build a level playing field where the rules fall on everyone equally. The prime example of human rules and rule following is language. In human societies, everyone learns and speaks a language. By following the rules of language, any individual can share information with any other individual who likewise follows the rules. Games are another simple example. People can play games together, because they agree to follow the same rules.

Humans follow rules because we agree to limit our behaviour for the sake of the collectivity. Language, games, and politics are examples of this uniquely human characteristic.

Businesses maximize their profits by minimizing the taxes they pay and keeping wages low. This strategy concentrates cash in a relatively few hands at the top when everybody who reads Prof. Krugman knows that economic vitality depends on cash passing through as many hands as possible.

Tax rebates and tax credits for low earners, and government spending to put people to work -- funded by taxes paid by people and institutions who can afford to pay them-- are good public policy but the exact opposite of what corporations and rich people would do.

Corporations and the rich think maximizing their own net worth is good economic policy, when in fact good economic policy spreads wealth around as much as possible.

"The real problem is not inadequate demand. The real problem is an overbearing government that regulates too much and taxes too much." --- Eric

Malarkey!

A real problem is inadequate demand. Executives invest in their business in anticipation of demand. If the demand is adequate their problem is supply.

In the "2008-2009 Great Recession" some $2 trillion in demand disappeared from the GDP when American household debt reached $14 trillion.

Households and businesses stopped spending. Households ran out of cash and businesses hoarded the cash they had despite the overly generous tax cuts of 2001 and 2003 that were intended to promote business reinvestment spending.

With neither business nor households spending the government increased spending but initially only at less than half of what had disappeared from the GDP. The Republicans in Congress were set against any additional increases.

A real problem has been that the federal government has not regulated enough to keep household debt increasing to where it finally strangled demand.

A real problem is that the government is not taxing enough to pay off the current national debt over the productive life time of its wage earners and the burden of the national debt is passed on to the next generation.
